text:
Jason Waddell turns his back on controversy as comeback continues to gain momentum MAT KERMEEN Last updated 18:01, February 5 2017 PHOTOSPORT 
Jason Waddell's comeback continues to get the thumbs up following Saturday's Group II win. 
Jason Waddell's return to race day riding took its most significant step on Saturday, but he insists the best is yet to come. 
Just over a month after he returned from a 12 month disqualification, Waddell reminded everybody of his class when winning the $100,000 Group II Waikato Guineas aboard Wyndspelle at Te Rapa on Saturday. 
Co-trainer of Wyndspelle and one of the best trainers in the country, Donna Logan, was one of many who were full of praise for Waddell's ride. Trish Dunell 
Jason Waddell takes a major step in his comeback with a Group II victory aboard Wyndspelle. 
Nobody has ever doubted Waddell's immense talent in the saddle, but at times he has been equally adept at finding trouble as he is the winning post. 
READ MORE: * Relief for trainers as apprentice jockey cleared of injury following career best win 
Back in December 2015, Waddell was disqualified for 12 months for acting detrimentally to the interests of racing and improper riding. 
At his hearing, it was alleged Waddell committed an act of deliberate interference and that he told a fellow jockey, he would do it again and was not concerned with the consequences. 
Waddell is no stranger to fronting disciplinary hearings, but the 2017 version of Jason Waddell seems to be a different, more mature man. 
The 30-year-old said his first month back has "exceeded all expectations". 
In 49 rides, Waddell has scored eight wins with seven seconds and six thirds. Only Opie Bosson, Leith Innes and Jacob Lowry have a better strike rate for riders who have had more than 40 starts this season. Ad Feedback 
Waddell says he owes that to the support of owners and trainers who have been happy to put him on quality horse flesh. 
Saturday's win was the icing on the cake for what has been a critical month of Waddell's career. 
"I couldn't have imagined it going any better. 
"Even just to be getting rides in the big races this season is a big thrill," he said. 
Waddell committed to the ride on Wyndspelle more than two weeks ago because he was so confident the Iffraaj colt could compete with the best three-year-old's in the country. 
Saturday's win was the first time Wyndspelle had come up with a decent draw, Logan said. But it was also the first time Waddell had been on his back. 
Waddell feels Wyndspelle has all the attributes a Derby horse needs and believes Saturday's run was the blueprint. 
He is keen to stick with Wyndspelle for the $1 million Group I New Zealand Derby (2400m) at Ellerslie on March 4 and it is hard to imagine connections would be looking past him. 
Following Saturday's win, bookmakers slashed Wyndspelle's Derby price in half from $18-$9. 
"I knew if he was three or four back on the rail he could go to sleep and then his turn of foot would put him right there at the finish. 
"He went to sleep like a pussy cat, he just idled along and didn't waste any energy until I asked him to go." 
As much as Waddell loves that wining feeling, following Saturday's victory, his thoughts were with the loyalty of the man who has been the rock behind his comeback - his manager Darryl Anderson. 
"He's always stood by me through thick and thin and we've become close friends," Waddell said. 
"Darryl's done a lot hard work, doing his homework and getting me the right rides and he'll be getting just as much of a kick out of this as I am, if not more." 
Waddell was always confident in his ability as a jockey, but has been surprised with how smoothly his return to the saddle has been. 
"It had been four years since I'd had the silks on at a race day so I wasn't expecting to be seeing things so clearly in a race and for my judgement to be as good as it is." 
Following Saturday's success, the logical next step for Waddell is to get back into the Group I grove. 
He has won five Group I races in New Zealand and has a Singapore Guineas victory. 
Waddell believes he has a great Oaks ride in Devise, who was a close second behind Nicoletta in the Group III Desert Gold Stakes at Trentham last week, and is obviously keen on Wyndspelle for the Derby but he is not getting ahead of himself. 
"I'm just taking it one day at a time, all I'm thinking about now is riding at Ellerslie on Wednesday." 
Waddell does not have a ride in Group I races, the NRM sprint and Herbie Dyke Stakes at Te Rapa on Saturday, but with his effort aboard Wyndspelle fresh in the minds of owners and trainers, that may change. 
He will ride Devise in the Group II Sir Cambridge Stud Sir Tristram Fillies Classic. - Stuff
